page.title: 13ECOLOGY KILGRASTON GROUNDS
page.content: There are formal lawns and wilder areas with shrubs,particularly rhododendrons, and trees, ranging from broad leafed oaks,sycamore,copper beech and flowering cherry to conifers Redwood,Douglas Fir,Norway Spruce and Scots Pine. Yew trees grow around the old cemetery where the Grant family are buried (this is the family that was living in Kilgraston before it was a school). A burn which is a tributary of the River Earn winds through the grounds. We found the soil in the burn more fertile than on the banks because fertilizers run off the nearby farms into the burn. We have many squirrels in the grounds but increasingly more grey than red. The squirrels feed on cones which they leave looking very untidy, unlike the
